Pixley Cogen Partners 

Pixley Cogen Partners is a co generation facility that is owned and operated by Calgren Renewable Fuels. The facility is operated by Calgren employees and will be following all of Calgren Renewable Fuels policies and procedures. Below is Calgren Renewable Fuels RMP. Pixley Cogen Partners will be following these policies and procedures.




Risk Management Plan
Introduction
This document was developed for the Facility located at 11704 Road 120, Calgren Renewable Fuels,
Pixley, CA 93256 in an effort to fulfill criteria of the RMP standard, as required by Section 112(r) of the
Clean Air Act and regulated by 40 CFR, Part 68.
Under the accidental release provisions of the Clean Air Act, regulated sources are required to conduct
hazard assessments, review off-site consequence analyses and develop a risk management plan. The
hazard assessment discusses off-site consequences for a Worst Case Scenario (WCS) and Alternative
Release Scenario (ARS) of the regulated substances(s) at this Facility. From the subsequent analyses
of the scenario(s), accident prevention programs will be reviewed, revised, and implemented.
Emergency response programs will also be reviewed/enhanced in an effort to minimize the impact of
the potential consequences resulting from an accidental release of regulated substances in the covered
process.
There are two primary purposes of the development of the Section 112(r) regulations, paraphrasing the
intents of the U.S. Congress and EPA:
1. To encourage sources to reduce the probability and severity of accidental releases
having the potential to cause harm to the public and the environment
2. To stimulate a dialogue between industry and the public to improve accident prevention
and emergency response
The RMP standard applies to facilities that store greater than a threshold quantity of a regulated
substance in a process at any one time. The facility has a process involving quantities toxics ammonia
above

the threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 pounds, listed in 40 CFR, Section 68.115. Therefore,
EPA's RMP applies. Toxics (ammonia) are the only substances in the Facility's current chemical usage
inventory, which would be present in quantities above the TQ limits set by the EPA, triggering the
requirement for submitting this RMP.
EPA has established three levels of performance within RMP development. Program 1 is the least
regulatory intensive, Program 3 is the most. In the first step, facilities must determine which of the
Page 1
 
three program levels apply for each "covered process". Once the Facility makes this determination,
there are four other steps (each step containing specific criteria depending on which program level
applies to the process), which must be fulfilled to complete the other aspects of the RMP. The other
elements of the RMP are outlined as follows and thoroughly defined within this document:
Applicability - Determines if the Facility is subject to the RMP rule and what program level of
compliance is applicable
Hazard Assessment (HA) - Conducts an off-site consequence analysis with worst-case and alternative
case release scenarios and includes a five-year accident history
Prevention Program (PP) - Identifies ways the Facility can prevent and detect accidental releases
Emergency Response Program (ERP) - Identifies methods the Facility uses to protect the public and
the environment from accidental releases
Risk Management "Plan" - Summarizes the Risk Management Program for submittal
The Facility is a conventional ethanol plant with a planned production of 63.25 million gallons/year of
denatured ethanol.
The quantity of anyhdrous ammonia used at the Facility is greater than the
threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, which is EPA's criteria for requiring the development and submittal
of information found in this RMP.
Anhydrous ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA standards. The same properties that make this
chemical valuable

for ethanol production also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions
in handling of this chemical to prevent unnecessary human exposure and to reduce the impact or threat
to nearby members of the community. Safety depends upon the manner in which the Facility handles
the chemical, combined with safety devices inherent in the design of this Facility, and the training of our
personnel.
Page 2
 
Risk Management Program Overview
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
It is this Facility's intent to uphold industry standards in the operation of the Facility and it is our policy to
adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The Facility has been designed and constructed
to be a state-of-the-art facility employing numerous release identification and prevention measures. If a
minor incident were to occur, in-house staff are trained and equipped to perform isolation measures
and secure leaking systems. If the incident escalates, Calgren Renewable Fuels would immediately
initiate the 911 system and the Tulare County Fire Department would respond to the emergency at the
Facility. The Tulare County Fire Department also has mutual aid agreements with other fire
departments and local HAZMAT Teams for additional emergency support should the need arise.
The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
The primary purpose of the toxics (ammonia) at this Facility is the production of ethanol. Physical
access by non-employees to the toxics (ammonia) is somewhat restricted by the general site fencing,
security cameras, and chemical contractor protocols/procedures and by the employees being on-site 24
hours, 7 days a week and 365 days per year. Within the Facility, the bulk anhydrous ammonia is near
the south west corner of the facility.
Anhydrous ammonia is a regulated toxic substance in accordance with the RMP regulation. The total
average daily use of aqueous ammonia at the Facility is approximately 120

pounds/day with a storage
capacity of 79,000 pounds in one tank. Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and delivered into the
17,864 gallon tank. The aqueous ammonia stored/used at the Facility is near the south west corner of
the facility.
Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenarios
In accordance with 40 CFR Part 60 Section 112r (the RMP regulations), an off-site consequence
analysis must be conducted and evaluated for each chemical (toxic and/or flammable) above the
regulated threshold quantity. The EPA's RMP modeling program, RMP Comp,
analysis.
was utilized for this
Page 3
 
WCS for Ammonia. Release of the entire contents of the largest single container, vessel or piping
configuration of aqueous ammonia would be 79,000 pounds. For WCS, according to EPA's RMP
modeling program, RMP Comp, TM the distance to toxic endpoint is 5.1 miles. The Facility is located in
a rural setting, with an estimated population of 7,800 persons residing within the 5.1 mile radius
(estimated from 2000 United States Census Data).
ARS for Ammonia. This is a more likely release scenario for the substance under normal operation
conditions. A release of 155 lbs/minute of ammonia for 10 minutes results in a distance to a toxic
endpoint of 0.2 miles. This distance will reach approximately 100 persons (estimated from United
States 2000 Census Data).
The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Specific Prevention Steps
This Facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state
codes and regulations. Calgren Renewable Fuels takes a systematic, proactive approach to evaluating
chemical processes.
Using this approach, the design, technology, operation and maintenance
activities, emergency preparedness plans, training, process changes and other elements that affect the
covered processes are all considered. By conducting thorough evaluations, accidental releases are
prevented and the consequences

cipation: Calgren Renewable Fuels has a philosophy and approach of
incorporating the knowledge and experience of our employees from all facets of
operation regarding the covered processes
¿
Contractors: Calgren Renewable Fuels upholds policies and procedures for safe work
practices of contractors on the Facility and a systematic approach of communicating
hazards inherent to the covered processes which the contractor may be working on or
near
Calgren Renewable Fuels employees are committed to the standards inherent in the RMP regulation.
Calgren Renewable Fuels has established specific accountabilities and controls that incorporate high
standards for accident prevention. Calgren has also developed a risk management system which
identifies specific job positions and responsibilities to facilitate proper management and implementation
of this RMP.
There have been no accidental releases ammonia, or other toxic/extremely hazardous chemicals in the
past five years, which have resulted in off-site consequences such as personal injury, death, or
response/restoration type activities.
Page 5
 
The Emergency Response Program
Calgren Renewable Fuels relies on trained, in-house staff and on-site equipment of for initial response
to incidental spills and releases (if safe to do so), and will acquire backup support from the Tulare
County Fire Department and HAZMAT representatives as needed.
Calgren Renewable Fuels will
discuss the content and intent of this program with the CDF Fire Department.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Besides the identified recommendations from the PHA's, Calgren Renewable Fuels intends to incorporate
updated maintenance and inspection procedures of the process equipment and operator training to facilitate the
mechanical integrity and the safe operation of this system. In addition, Calgren Renewable Fuels is in the
process of updating the existing safety program to reflect current conditions at the Facility. Calgren Renewable

Fuels also plans on conducting table-top drills with the local emergency agency in order to be better prepared for
possible accident/release scenarios.
Applicability
The Facility has a process involving quantities of toxics (ammonia) above the threshold quantity (TQ) of
10,000 pounds, listed in 40 CFR, Section 68.115. Therefore, EPA's RMP applies. Toxic (ammonia) is
the only substances in the Facility's current chemical usage inventory, which would be present in
quantities above the TQ limits set by the EPA, triggering the requirement for submitting this RMP.
Program Level Determination
Determining which program level the Facility is subject to within the RMP Guidelines requires
development of a WCS and/or Off-site Consequence Analysis (OCA) and a review of the Facility's
accident history with respect to the covered process for the previous five years.
Calgren Renewable Fuels is not eligible for Program 1 because the distance to hazardous endpoint
derived in the WCS includes public receptors. Also, Calgren Renewable Fuels process involving toxic
(ammonia) is subject to OSHA's PSM Program requirements. Therefore, Calgren Renewable Fuels
has a "Program 3" process involving toxic (ammonia).
Page 6
 
Hazard Assessment Elements
The next step for RMP development is to conduct the hazard assessment. The essential elements of
this assessment are as follows:
¿
¿
¿
¿
¿
¿
Off-site consequence analysis parameters (discussed in worst-case and alternative
release scenarios)
WCS analysis (completed in subsequent section of this document)
ARS analysis (one for each toxic chemical, completed in subsequent section of this
document)
Defining off-site impacts on population. Population estimates and identification of major
public receptors (i.e., schools, hospitals, other businesses, public roads)
Defining off-site impacts on the environment. Identification of any national or state parks,
federal wilderness areas, officially designated wildlife refuges,

etc
Review and update. Calgren Renewable Fuels will review and update this RMP at least
once every five years as required by the standard. Also, if changes to the process occur
which might reasonably be expected to alter the distance to endpoint calculations, the
plan will be reviewed and changes implemented within six months of such alterations
¿
¿
Documentation. Calgren Renewable Fuels will maintain derived records and subsequent
documents generated as a result of this analysis
Calgren Renewable Fuels will maintain a five-year accident history of all accidental
releases from the covered process which result in deaths, injuries, or significant property
damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuation, sheltering in place,
property damage, or environmental damage. Facility has had no incidents in the last five
years resulting in any reportable occurrences as described by Section 68.42
Worst Case Scenario Analysis
Using the specified conditions set forth in the RMP Guidance EPA 550-B-98-110 and the EPA's
modeling program, RMP CompTM, the distance to "toxic" endpoint for anhydrous ammonia is 5.1 miles.
Using 2000 Census Data, the estimated population within this radius is 7800 persons.
Page 7
 
Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) Analysis
An ARS is required for each toxic chemical held at the Facility above the TQ specified in Section
68.115 for facilities having Program 3 processes. This includes completing an ARS for the chemical
used in the WCS, as well as an ARS for each additional toxic chemical present in quantities above the
TQ. The ARS's are to be developed with the additional criteria that they must be: 1) more likely to
occur than the WCS and 2) the distance to endpoint is greater than the distance to the nearest public
receptor, if such a scenario exists. In the ARS, some of the specified weather conditions are changed
with respect to the WCS and one is permitted to consider active mitigation systems, which would lim

it
the release of the chemical.
Using the specified conditions set forth in exhibit 4-12 and 4-20 of the RMP Guidance EPA 550-B-98-
010 and the EPA's modeling program, RMP Comp,

the distance to the toxic endpoint for anhydrous
ammonia is 0.2 miles. Modeling results defining the distance to toxic endpoint and population estimates
of the affected area.

2.5.1
Process Safety Information
Calgren Renewable Fuels has developed and maintains written information relating to the ammonia
system. This information was used by PHA team to conduct their PHA during March of 2011. It is the
EH&S Coordinator  responsibility to update and maintain this information. Future PHA teams will use
this information during the required periodic compliance audits of this RMP. The process diagrams,
equipment specifications and technology information involved in this system is referenced in section of
this manual.
Hazard Review
PHA's were conducted using the "What If" methodology for identifying potential hazardous
consequences, causes, safeguards and hazard mitigation actions.
This What If assessment was
facilitated by Mr. Paul Lopez 

Operating Procedures
Calgren Renewable Fuels has developed SOPs for its systems using hazardous chemicals. Operating
procedures include operating limits, consequences of process deviation and steps to correct or avoid
deviations. Safety and health considerations have been included in these procedures. Safety systems
and their functions have also been identified. 

The Production Manager will review the operating procedures annually so

that the procedures reflect
the current operating practices. The Production Manager will also review the following safety practices
and polices:
¿
¿
¿
¿
Respiratory protection
Lockout/tagout
Confined space entry
Opening process equipment or piping
Page 9
 
¿
¿
Control entrance into a facility by maintenance contractor, vendor, or other support
personnel
Safety program / hazard communication / employee right-to-know program
Training
Calgren Renewable Fuels is committed to establishing the safest possible environment for its
employees and the community surrounding its operations. Calgren has established a comprehensive
training program to meet the requirements under both the EPA's RMP Standard and OSHA's PSM
Standard. The essential elements of this program are found in section 1.5 of this manual.
Calgren Renewable Fuels has established initial and refresher training modules for several safety
programs. The Facility's operators and maintenance personnel are provided training on an annual
basis. The EH&S Manager of the plant will coordinate and document the provided safety training.
Contractors (if used at all) are provided training based on the work they conduct on or adjacent to the
ammonia system. Their employers are responsible for providing OSHA-mandated training. Calgren
Renewable Fuels will provide the appropriate training to contractors required by the RMP and PSM
Standards as they pertain to the ammonia system.
Mechanical Integrity
The maintenance programs and schedules are in-place and periodically reviewed to facilitate proper
"ongoing" mechanical integrity. The basic contents of these programs are found in previous sections of
this manual.
This section applies to the following process equipment:
1. Pressure vessels and storage tanks
2. Piping systems (including piping components such as valves)
3. Relief and vent systems and devices
4. Emergency shutdown systems
Page 10
 
5. Controls (including monitoring devices, an

d alarms)
Written procedures to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment have been implemented.
The written procedures include a list of pressure vessels, storage tanks, process piping, relief and vent
systems, fire system components, emergency shutdown systems, alarms, pumps and peripheral
equipment.
Each employee involved in maintaining the ongoing integrity of process equipment will be trained in an
overview of those processes and their hazards and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job
tasks to assure that the employee can perform the job tasks in a safe manner.
Inspections and tests performed on process equipment follow recognized and generally accepted good
engineering practices.
Each inspection and test that is performed on process equipment is
documented. Deficiencies in equipment that are outside acceptable limits will be corrected in a safe
and timely manner before further use to assure safe operation.
In the construction of new facilities and changes in current equipment, assurance will be made by the
Plant Manager that equipment, as it is fabricated, is suitable for the process application for which it
will be used. Appropriate checks and inspections will be performed so that that equipment is installed
properly and consistent with design specifications and the manufacturer's instructions. Maintenance
materials, spare parts and equipment will be suitable for the process application for which they will be
used. These issues will be properly addressed as defined by the MOC procedures.
Field equipment installation work will be inspected for use of proper materials and procedures to verify
that qualified craft workers do the job.
The use of appropriate gaskets, packing, bolts, valves,
lubricants and welding rods will be verified in the field. Also, procedures for installing safety devices will
be verified in the field, such as the torque on the bolts on rupture disc installations, uniform torque on
flange bolts

and proper installation of pump seals.
Management of Change (MOC)
MOC procedures for the covered process are defined in Management of Change MOC section of the
PSM program manual. Calgren Renewable Fuels has developed a procedure to manage process
Page 11
 
changes. MOC procedures include changes in chemical, operating procedures, or system
components. The Plant Manager, Production Manager and the Maintenance Manager shall approve
of any changes before they are implemented.
It is the Plant Manager's responsibility to verify that identified items on the checklist requiring action
are completed. All requirements will be addressed prior to the changes to any process, chemical,
operating procedures, or system component modifications.
Pre-Start-up Safety Review (PSSR)
Procedures for conducting PSSRs are given in PSM Section of this manual. Calgren Renewable Fuels
will conduct a PSSR prior to a new process startup or when changes are made other than replacement
of kind to the existing systems.
The plant management staff will determine if a process change
qualifies as a "modification" or "replacement of kind". Modifications to the process will require a pre-
startup review before any startup can occur.
Compliance Audits
Calgren Renewable Fuels will evaluate and certify compliance of RMP regulations at least every three
years, to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the rule are still adequate and are
being followed. The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in RMP
and/or the process.
Calgren Renewable Fuels will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of
the findings of the compliance audit and document that deficiencies have been corrected. Calgren
Renewable Fuels will retain the two most recent compliance audit reports on-site. This requirement
does not apply to any compliance audit report that is more than five years old.
Incident Investigation
Calgren Renewable Fu

els will investigate each incident (or near miss) which resulted in, or could
reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a hazardous chemical. An incident investigation
will be initiated as promptly as possible, but not later than 24 hours following the incident.
Page 12
 
The EH&S Coordinator will use the Incident Report form along with the review of Management to summarize and 
report any findings from the incident investigation and follow investigation items outlined on the incident report.
 

Calgren Renewable Fuels will promptly address and resolve the investigation findings and
recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions will be documented and maintained as part of
the RMP. The findings will be reviewed with affected personnel. Investigation summaries will be
retained for five years.
Employee Participation
Calgren Renewable Fuels believes firmly in, and is committed to, employee participation in the
PSM/RMP development and implementation. Involvement will lead to a better understanding by all of
the hazards, operating procedures, safety systems, start-up procedures, shutdown procedures,
training, contractor involvement, maintenance, emergency planning and emergency response
necessary to implement a full and complete program
Employees (or an employee representative) will be directly involved in developing each of the following
PSM / RMP elements:
¿
¿
¿
¿
¿
¿
¿
Process hazard analysis
Process hazard analysis revalidation
Operating procedures
Process maintenance procedures
Management of change procedures
Incident investigation procedures
Emergency planning and response procedures
Affected employees will be asked for suggestions and remarks pertaining to the PSM/RMP programs
during many of the other related safety training courses (i.e., hazard communication (employee right-to-
know), emergency response plans, lockout/tagout, hot work program, etc.). The suggestions will then
be acted on and the results com

municated to the employees.
Page 13

 
Upon request, Calgren Renewable Fuels provides to employees (or their representatives) access to
elements of the PSM/RMP Programs. The Plant Manager or Production Manager will keep a copy of
this program for employee access.
Contractors
Calgren Renewable Fuels is concerned with the safety and welfare of their employees. Calgren wants
to be consistent in contract administration involving the safety responsibilities of contractors.

The contractor's implementation of their own safety program is an important part of Calgren's safety
program. Each contractor working on or near the covered process must comply with federal and state
occupational safety and health regulations. Contractor health and safety concerns with respect to the
PSM/RMP requirements for the covered processes will be handled in accordance with section 1.6 of
this manual.
Risk Management Plan Submittal
The EPA requires submittal of an abbreviated version (Plan) of the original RMP to USEPA by June 21,
1999, or on the date the Facility stores any regulated substance above the applicable threshold
quantity; and the rule requires five-year resubmittals to update revisions on the original Plan within five
years after the first implementation of the Facility's RMP.
The Plan includes the executive summary of this document, a signed certification statement regarding
the content and accuracy of the RMP and specific data elements outlined by the EPA in their RMP
Emergency Response
Calgren Renewable Fuels will use local and state emergency responders to respond to ammonia
releases. The emergency response team's actions and employee evacuation will aid in the prevention
of a catastrophic event from occurring. The responding groups, Tulare County Fire Department and
Hazardous Materials Response (HAZMAT) Teams are comprised of area fire department personnel
trained in HAZMAT responses. These teams are the designated emergency responders to leaks,
sp

ills, fires and releases of significant hazardous materials at Calgren Renewable Fuels Facility. The
Page 14
 
local/state regional HAZMAT team will implement their incident command system to manage the
emergency response.
Calgren Renewable Fuels employees will only respond to incidental spills/releases within the
immediate spill or release area (if it is safe to do so) and if the incident escalates, will evacuate and
initiate the 911 emergency system "simultaneously".
Response procedures will involve isolating the area and evacuating all nonessential employees. A
hazard assessment will be conducted, in order to determine the resources needed. Ammonia release
will be controlled, contained, or confined by the local or regional HAZMAT teams to prevent further
damage or injury.
The responding team will critique the emergency response upon completing response procedures. The
response team commander(s) will facilitate the critique session.
